steps.title: üéØ Find the Verb!
steps.instruction: Find the verb in the sentence. Decide: Is it a 'Condition' or an 'Action'?
steps.investigation: Investigation: 'habe' comes from 'haben' (to have). This is not a condition verb, so it's an ACTION!

steps.title: üëë Find the BOSS!
steps.instruction: To find the boss of the sentence, use this question:
steps.investigation: Investigation: 'Wer oder was habe?' ‚Üí 'Ich' (I). The BOSS is always Nominative!

steps.title: üéØ Find the VICTIM!
steps.instruction: To find the victim of the action, use this question:
steps.investigation: Investigation: 'Wen oder was habe ich?' ‚Üí 'Bruder' (brother). This is our VICTIM!

steps.title: ‚öñÔ∏è PUT THE VICTIM BEHIND BARS!
steps.instruction: The VICTIM always goes into the ACCUSATIVE case.
steps.result:
Evidence: The victim is 'Bruder' (masculine: der Bruder)
Law: Accusative changes masculine articles: der ‚Üí den, ein ‚Üí einen

caseTitle: üïµÔ∏è THE CASE: 'The dog helps the man.'

steps.title: üéØ Find the Verb!
steps.instruction: Find the verb in the sentence.
steps.investigation: Investigation: The verb is 'hilft' (from 'helfen' - to help). This verb commonly takes a Dative object.

steps.title: üëë Find the BOSS!
steps.instruction: Who or what is performing the action?
steps.investigation: Investigation: 'Wer oder was hilft?' ‚Üí 'Der Hund' (The dog). The BOSS is Nominative!

steps.title: ü§ù Find the 'Helper' Object!
steps.instruction: Some verbs need a 'helper' or 'receiver' of the action. To find this Dative object, ask:
steps.investigation: Investigation: 'Wem hilft der Hund?' ‚Üí 'Mann' (man). The object receiving the help is in the DATIVE case!

steps.title: ‚öñÔ∏è DETERMINE THE ARTICLE!
steps.instruction: The object is Dative. Now find the correct article.
steps.result:
Evidence: The object is 'Mann' (masculine: der Mann)
Law: Dative changes masculine articles: der ‚Üí dem, ein ‚Üí einem
